Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Integrating Multiple Biomarkers in Nano-Sensor Arrays for Enhanced Detection of Prostate Cancer

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The National Science Foundation uses the Early-concept Grants for Exploratory Research (EAGER) funding mechanism to support exploratory work in its early stages on untested, but potentially transformative, research ideas or approaches. This EAGER project was awarded as a result of the invitation in the Dear Colleague Letter NSF 16-080 to proposers from Historically Black Colleges and Universities to submit proposals that would strengthen research capacity of faculty at the institution. The project at Tennessee State University aims to design and develop nano-cantilever resonators functionalized with multiple biomarkers to provide for an accurate, highly sensitive, fast, and low-cost method for the detection of prostate cancer.

This project seeks to explore the feasibility of integrating multiple biomarkers in a nano-cantilever array to provide for an accurate, highly sensitive, fast, and low-cost method for the detection of prostate cancer. The sensor cantilever array will be designed and fabricated, each cantilever will be functionalized with a different biomarker, and the response from the array will be measured and mapped together to provide a model for detecting prostate cancer. It is proposed that the sensor array will generate more data about the sample to be analyzed and provide for a more accurate and specific detection method, reducing the number of false positives generated. The main tasks to be completed to achieve this objective are: the design of the nano-cantilevers; fabrication of the nano-electromechanical systems devices; functionalizing the nano-resonator surfaces, including the conjugation of the gold nanoparticles with each of the four biomarkers to be used and the application of each bio-substrate on a nano-cantilever; and testing of the nano-cantilever array. This work could be expanded in the future to provide a framework for the use of multiple biomarkers for other sensing mechanisms where specificity and sensitivity are an issue.

This EAGER project is funded by the Engineering Directorate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this research was to explore the feasibility of integrating multiple biomarkers in a nano-cantilever array to provide for an accurate, highly sensitive, fast, and low-cost method for the detection of prostate cancer. The nano-cantilevers were designed based on finite element analysis using COMSOL software and theoretical equations to investigate the device dimensions for optimal performance.  The goal was to find a configuration that yields the greatest deflection as a result of analytes selectively binding onto the antibody-conjugated gold nanoparticles immobilized on the cantilever surface.  From these results, a cantilever design incorporating a sensing pad with nanostructures on the free end was implemented, as shown in Figure 1 (dimensions:  2.8 μm x 0.8 μm x 0.1μm).  The nano-cantilevers were fabricated using micro- and nano-fabrication techniques and equipment as shown in Figure 2.  They were then functionalized with monoclonal antibody-conjugated gold nanoparticles (mAb-cGNP). The testing of these cantilevers show that they are specific, selective and sensitive to the antigens they were individually detecting. It was also shown that the combination of the mAb-cGNP and the fabricated nano-cantilever improved the minimum detectability sensitivity. This result is very important since there are a large number of biomarkers (including some of the biomarkers used in this study for monitoring prostate cancer) that may be found in minute quantities in blood. The ability to detect such small quantities and amplify their response opens the door for more biomarkers to be used in a clinical setting for point-of-care diagnostics.  The broader impact of the project is the research training of student researchers in the emerging area of nano-materials and devices for biomedical applications. To-date, one graduate and five undergraduate students have been trained via research experiences as well as seminars on biomedical and micro-/nano-electromechanical systems (MEMS/NEMS) devices and processing techniques.  The majority of the students were minority or female students.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The objective of this research was to explore the feasibility of integrating multiple biomarkers in a nano-cantilever array to provide for an accurate, highly sensitive, fast, and low-cost method for the detection of prostate cancer. The nano-cantilevers were designed based on finite element analysis using COMSOL software and theoretical equations to investigate the device dimensions for optimal performance. The goal was to find a configuration that yields the greatest deflection as a result of analytes selectively binding onto the antibody-conjugated gold nanoparticles immobilized on the cantilever surface. From these results, a cantilever design incorporating a sensing pad with nanostructures on the free end was implemented, as shown in Figure 1 (dimensions: 2.8 μm x 0.8 μm x 0.1μm). The nano-cantilevers were fabricated using micro- and nano-fabrication techniques and equipment as shown in Figure 2. They were then functionalized with monoclonal antibody-conjugated gold nanoparticles (mAb-cGNP). The testing of these cantilevers show that they are specific, selective and sensitive to the antigens they were individually detecting. It was also shown that the combination of the mAb-cGNP and the fabricated nano-cantilever improved the minimum detectability sensitivity. This result is very important since there are a large number of biomarkers (including some of the biomarkers used in this study for monitoring prostate cancer) that may be found in minute quantities in blood. The ability to detect such small quantities and amplify their response opens the door for more biomarkers to be used in a clinical setting for point-of-care diagnostics. The broader impact of the project is the research training of student researchers in the emerging area of nano-materials and devices for biomedical applications. To-date, one graduate and five undergraduate students have been trained via research experiences as well as seminars on biomedical and micro-/nano-electromechanical systems (MEMS/NEMS) devices and processing techniques. The majority of the students were minority or female students. Last Modified: 01/15/2019 Submitted by: Frances R Williams
